options.text: Partial pressure of CO<sub>2</sub> (PCO<sub>2</sub>,) is higher in the air inside the lungs
Partial pressure of O<sub>2</sub> (PO<sub>2</sub> ) is higher in the air inside the lungs
Partial pressure of O<sub>2</sub> (PO<sub>2</sub>) is lower inside the venous blood than in the air in the lung
Partial pressure of CO<sub>2</sub> (PCO<sub>2</sub>) is higher inside the venous blood than in the air

solution.text: Partial pressure of O<sub>2 </sub>in the atmospheric air is 158 mm of Hg and that of CO<sub>2</sub> is 0.3 mm of Hg. Partial pressure of oxygen PO<sub>2</sub> in alveolar air is 100 mm Hg and it is only 40 mm Hg in the arterial capillaries of the lungs. Therefore, oxygen from the alveolar air rapidly diffuses due to its higher PO<sub>2</sub> into the blood capillaries. Hence, Partial pressure of CO<sub>2</sub> (PCO<sub>2</sub>) is lower in the air inside the lungs.
